The Lycurgus Cup is a jade colored chalice from the Roman Empire. Outside of interesting carvings upon it, I'm not particularly impressed, until the proprietor moves the chalice in front of a flame, and I watch as the jade coloring shifts to red.\n  "Interesting yes? And not only light causes this. Add your drink of choice, and you'll see the color altered as well. It's said by some that the secret to how they crafted such a chalice was lost with the fall of Rome."\n  I find myself mesmerized as they turn the cup before the flame and I watch as the color rotates are the cup, the changing of green and red giving the carvings on the cup a very captivating look. A water clock is an interesting device. Constructed in such a way that it can track the passage of time by water level.\n  On the interior of the container are markings that are used to show the passage of time. As the water leaves the container, one can see where the water is level with the lines and tell how much time has passed. It's also impressive on how it appears simple in design, yet it's exact measurements give it a reliability that is often not considered or taken for granted in other craftsmanship.\n  I can even picture where I'd display such a device. The Derrynaflan Chalice is an advanced piece of Irish metalworking, made largely of silver and gold, with amber studs. It's sturdier than other chalices of similar design, as its three main components (cup, stem and foot) are connected more securely, by means of a hollow stem rather than a copper bolt.\n  A worthy piece for any practicing Christian to have in their collection.

Principles on Etiquette. A book that written with the intention of educating young nobles and families who often interact with them, to reduce the chances of an embarrassing situation.\n  Most of this isn't really new, yet there are a few things I can likely reinforce by using it.

A scandalous book that is said to be based off the diary of a Queen's handmaiden, who gives a look at the inner workings of a court and the petty rivalries and intrigue that takes place.\n  Much of it is clearly fiction, yet there are some pretty clever portions of it that give me some ideas.

Roman Roads. A book that takes a look not only at the facet of construction that was labor based, but also considerations in to where and why roads were built. The financial costs and funding mechanisms of the roads, and the resulting impacts on the economy for the regions connected by the roads.\n  Nothing ground breaking in what I'm already aware of, yet there are few things I've not considered.

Infantry Leads the Way. A military manual on different formations and training exercises to address common battlefield situations.\n  Most of this isn't really new, yet there are a few things I can likely reinforce by using it.

Mediterranean Mysteries. A book that tries to figure out mysteries using facts and logic.\n  While entertaining, the book holds additional value if one considers applying the same logical thought processes to solving other unknowns.
